The Bluesky Developer Guidelines are not legally enforceable by end users, but they're enforceable by Bluesky, and making the request is the first step.

historically speaking, unless they have enough juice to file criminal charges, lawyers are not especially effective at deterring people who don't believe in copyright on the internet

GDPR has enough teeth that people doing stuff with data like this are often blissfully unaware of just how badly they‚Äôre setting themselves up for a legal thrashing if someone is motivated to screw with them for it.
Show us that you have no fucking clue what you're talking about by showing us that you have no fucking clue what you're talking about.
This is exactly how the CCPA and GDPR work; people are entitled to request deletion like this.

Good to know regarding CCPA.  What I had read all mentioned either an in person request with the vendor, phone call to the vendor, email to vendor, or a web form via the vendors website.   There wasn't any mention about a skeet/tweet/other social media post.

Data access requests over social media are considered legitimate in the EU. 

‚ÄúIndividuals can make subject access requests on any social media site where an organisation has a presence.‚Äù

record.text: Zenodo, as part of CERN, provides a way for data subjects to request the removal of their personal data from data sets. HuggingFace does not, as far as I have been able to determine.

Do you know that Zenodo‚Äôs personal data removal is actually effective?  If one of the many Bluesky users who are so against inclusion asked for removal, would we see a promptly generated new version of the dataset I linked to?  I can‚Äôt find any version history there‚Ä¶

The dataset on Zenodo has no user names etc., those are replaced by numbers (see the paper). 

There are also some data sets on HF without any author information, i.e., only the text posts.
Yeah, that‚Äôs common practice, but it‚Äôs also completely reversible with a tiny bit of querying to Bluesky‚Äôs API‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ which just proves how silly a lot of the discussion is. The API is dead simple to use, you can fit a program to download all posts in a tweet. Some users genuinely weren‚Äôt aware, others don‚Äôt want to be
They‚Äôre hosted by CERN, which requires its affiliates to honor those policies ‚Äî they have to under their special NGO status. The website links to CERN‚Äôs data subject removal request form.

Ok, that sounds plausible (but I‚Äôm still surprised to not see any trail of new versions, maybe it‚Äôs done in place?).

HuggingFace is mostly based in Paris, and EU companies which have been around longer that a few years and are data heavy tend to be careful about this too.
Is it? The information I was able to find said it was in NY. If it‚Äôs in Paris, then this could be a very costly mistake indeed.
NY legal HQ, widely distributed staff but largest office in Paris, I think?

It doesn‚Äôt matter if HF is HQed in Paris or NY, GDPR applies to any company in the world that processes personal data (PD) collected in the EU. Same for the UK & Switzerland. Also, opt-out is not a legal way to view, collect, or use (‚Äúprocess‚Äù) PD in the EU; publicly-available PD is still PD there.
re: data removal at HF, it looks like emailing privacy@huggingface.co is the only avenue I‚Äôve seen
And the fact that the OP was blocking people who ask for the process is not a good sign.
as far as I can tell the OP is a tiny rando account that did this for the purpose of shitposting (negative sense) about it; you can find more official HF folks over at @hf.co

record.text: Sure, but this I'd argue is a slightly different issue. NYT and other news publishers, author articles behind paid access. If that is not enough grounds for copyright claims, I don't know what is.

2/2: By packaging my content without my consent or permission, alpindale.bsky.social is taking that from me without any consideration or recourse.

Laws are just as relevant for the little people as they are for the big companies.
That‚Äôs a fair assessment, may I ask, would you also be similarly inclined if a streetphotographer unknowingly captured you and sold pictures with you on it?

I'd cut the photographer some slack, because I don't expect the photo to adversely affect my own rights in the future.

A relevant analogy would be me setting my security camera to capture faces of everyone walking past it and then making that collection of faces available online. Not cool at all.

1/2: And one other point that I made over on the Hugging Face forum: as a content author, I have an economic interest in maintaining the right to be able to license my content to someone training an LLM, the same as various companies are selling to LLM companies to train on the content they control.

It's the same issue.

Whether it's behind a paywall is beside the point. There are plenty of sites/blogs that don't sit behind paywalls that I'm STILL prohibited from copying the entirety of and redistributing as a paid product. I can't just take The Verge and print it as a book and redistribute it.
